title: Head Wound Management
summary: Care for scalp lacerations and head wounds, with attention to potential brain injury and proper bleeding control.

steps.title: Assess Consciousness and Call for Help
steps.description: Check if the person is conscious and alert. Ask their name, where they are, and what happened. If unconscious, confused, or the wound is severe, call 911 immediately. Head wounds often bleed heavily but may not be as serious as they appear.

steps.title: Control Bleeding with Direct Pressure
steps.description: Apply firm, direct pressure to the wound using a sterile gauze or clean cloth. Head wounds tend to bleed profusely due to many blood vessels in the scalp. Maintain pressure for 10 minutes without peeking.

steps.title: Check for Other Injuries
steps.description: While maintaining pressure, check for other injuries, especially neck or spine injuries. Do not move the person if you suspect spinal injury. Look for clear fluid from nose or ears which may indicate skull fracture.

steps.title: Apply a Dressing
steps.description: Once bleeding is controlled, apply a sterile dressing. If the wound is large, you may need to hold the edges together. Secure with a bandage wrapped around the head, being careful not to wrap too tightly.

steps.title: Monitor for Concussion Signs
steps.description: Watch for signs of concussion: confusion, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, severe headache, unequal pupils, or difficulty staying awake. These may appear immediately or hours later.

steps.title: Keep Person Calm and Still
steps.description: Have the person sit or lie down comfortably with head and shoulders slightly elevated if no spinal injury is suspected. Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth to reduce swelling. Continue monitoring until help arrives.

warnings: Head wounds can bleed heavily even when not serious
Never ignore signs of concussion or brain injury
Clear fluid from ears or nose may indicate skull fracture
Do not give pain medication that may mask symptoms
whenToSeekHelp: Confusion, memory loss, or behavior changes
Weakness, numbness, or problems with coordination
Deep cut that may need stitches
preventionTips: Wear appropriate helmets for sports and cycling
Use proper head protection in construction areas
Install grab bars in bathrooms to prevent falls
